[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures (e.g., first paragraph);

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from geographic description to village encounter;
[CLARITY]: Dense, unconnected ethnographic details (e.g., language comparisons).

[SYNTAX]: Awkward phrasing in comparisons (e.g., "like that of the Khirgis")

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between topics (e.g., physical traits to equipment mishap)
[STRUCTURE]: Disruptive insertion of author’s logistical issue amid descriptive flow

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally long, complex sentences (e.g., wedding customs description)

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transition from descriptive customs to statistical table
[TRANSITION]: Lack of explicit links between subsections (e.g., death customs → marriage → livestock data)
[LOGIC]: Statistical data contradicts prior claims of population decline (unclear resolution)

[SYNTAX]: Occasional overly complex sentence structures (e.g., "Now the horses climbed...").
[LEXICON]: Uncommon units like "fathoms" for height may cause minor confusion.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transition from describing terrain to mentioning guardhouses without contextual link.
[CLARITY]: Assumed knowledge of terms like "Tangutan Prince" or "Khirgis" without explanation.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally long, complex sentences may impede immediate clarity.
[LEXICON]: Archaisms (e.g., "capacious houses") and less common terms (e.g., "four-cornered beams") require brief pauses for interpretation.

[TRANSITION]: Subtle abruptness between architectural descriptions and interpersonal/cultural details (e.g., shift from temple layout to lamas’ fear of instruments).
[STRUCTURE]: Minor repetition in thematic focus (e.g., repeated emphasis on Buddhist icons without explicit connective tissue).

[SPELLING]: Typographical errors (e.g., "wre" instead of "we", "thau" instead of "than").
[SYNTAX]: Occasionally awkward sentence structure (e.g., "if possible even steeper").

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between descriptive, geographical, and historical topics.
[CLARITY]: Assumes prior knowledge of terms (e.g., "t'umu", "fu-fumu", locations).
[STRUCTURE]: Topics (e.g., origin myths, governance) feel loosely connected without explicit links.

[SYNTAX]: Complex, archaic sentence structures may impede readability.
[LEXICON]: Unexplained specialized terms (e.g., "tshi", tribal designations) assume domain knowledge.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transitions between historical, administrative, and cultural sections.
[CLARITY]: Dense, unsegmented blocks of detailed information (e.g., "bones" classifications, tax tables).

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex, nested sentence structures (e.g., detailed descriptions of costume).

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt topic shifts (e.g., marriage → physical traits → clothing) without transitional links.
[CLARITY]: Ideas within paragraphs are clear, but overall flow lacks logical progression between sections.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between paragraphs (e.g., meals → tents → livestock grievances)
[STRUCTURE]: Lacking explicit connectors between ideas (e.g., New Year’s rifle practice feels disconnected)

[SPELLING]: Typographical error ("reined iu" instead of "reined in").
[SYNTAX]: Occasionally dense, overly complex sentence structures (e.g., "The valley of the Kluadjek-gol...").

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from geographical description to arrival in Li-yen.
[CLARITY]: Assumes prior knowledge of Potanin and the Dungan revolt.
[STRUCTURE]: Minor disjointedness between travelogue and historical/contextual details.
